channel.title: Installing Java and Flash player on Ubuntu 9.04
channel.description:
I recently installed Ubuntu 9.04 on my computer, and I'm getting used to it. I don't really have a clue where everything is, and how to install things.
I'm wanting to install Java and Flash player (For YouTube and Runescape/Runescape Private servers), and also possibly the Java Development Kit. I've attempted to install Java myself; it's in the directory '/usr/java/jre1.6.0_14' but it doesn't seem to work.
Could someone take me through this, and is there something like Teamviewer/Remote control that you could help me with?
Thanks.

item.title: Installing Java and Flash player on Ubuntu 9.04
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

chrisn2323:

sudo apt-get install ubuntu-restricted-extras installs everything you need (java, flash, mp3 etc.)

Yes, the MP3 plugin was another thing I needed, I’ll try that when I can be bothered to go on Ubuntu, which will most likely be tomorrow as it’s 1:42 AM so I’m on Windows atm.

Read full topic
item.source: Installing Java and Flash player on Ubuntu 9.04

item.title: Installing Java and Flash player on Ubuntu 9.04
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

sudo apt-get install flashplugin-nonfree

That will install flash just fine, then you want to:

sudo apt-get install sun-java6-plugin sun-java6-jdk

and that will install the sun java version 6 JRE, browser plugin, and JDK.

How easy was that?

Read full topic

primadude just search for flashplugin-nonfree in synaptic.

item.title: Installing Java and Flash player on Ubuntu 9.04
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/howto-ubuntu-linux-install-configure-jdk-jre/
http://psychocats.net/ubuntu/flash

you might also want to check the ubuntu wiki.

also, for future linux questions, post in the linux forum.

edit: i just noticed this in the flash article:

If you are using Ubuntu 9.04, this tutorial will be useless to you. I don't know what plugin Ubuntu tries to use by default (Gnash and Swfdec are not installed), but it tries to play YouTube instead of prompting you to display a plugin. So you can either install all the major proprietary codecs [ http://psychocats.net/ubuntu/nonfree ] or just install flashplugin-nonfree. If you don't know how to install software in Ubuntu, read this [ http://psychocats.net/ubuntu/installingsoftware ].

Read full topic
